awd_titl_txt: RAISE: TAQS: Materials spectroscopy for next generation superconducting qubits
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description:  Quantum computers can perform calculations that are beyond the capabilities of current classical computers and, if successfully developed, would revolutionize many aspects of science, technology, and commerce. The performance of present-day, small quantum computers is limited by interference from background noise that prevents useful computations from being done. This noise can arise from imperfections in the materials used in the prototypes - materials selected for other favorable properties - and the goal of this project is to discover which materials cause the noise, and how to improve or replace them.  In doing so, this research could not only impact quantum computers; the development of low noise materials could also be useful in creating better sensors and more sensitive signal amplifiers. This project also serves to train a new generation of scientists who are conversant across several fields, including quantum information science, experimental condensed matter physics, materials growth, and device engineering. This project includes a program to help students perform research at both academic and industry labs, specifically at the IBM Quantum Computing group in Yorktown Heights, NY. This training is necessary for the development of a workforce that can spearhead future quantum information science and quantum engineering.

Technical description:  This collaborative, interdisciplinary research effort between academia and industry brings together advanced methods in materials science, physics and electrical engineering to solve long-standing, fundamental problems in superconducting (SC) qubit devices. Although SC qubits are one of the leading candidates for quantum computing, their coherence times are currently insufficient for most applications. Despite significant progress in extending qubit coherence over the last 20 years, the microscopic sources of loss and noise remain generally unknown. This project utilizes direct material and surface spectroscopy tools to determine the chemical and physical nature of defects in state-of-the-art SC qubit devices, and correlates that characterization with qubit performance to discover the defects that are the sources of the decoherence. Using this information, the research team devises new surface treatments and fabrication techniques aimed at removing those defects, and those techniques are employed to fabricate and measure new prototype qubits. Building on this knowledge, the research team also explores alternative materials systems that are chemically inert, display low microwave loss, and can be grown with ultrahigh purity as substrates for qubits. This research effort is structured as a virtuous cycle in which knowledge gained from fundamental materials spectroscopy is rapidly translated into advances in qubit device fabrication, providing feedback to identify entirely new materials systems and new qubit designs, using theoretical support to develop new methods for benchmarking qubit performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant has fueled the development of innovative qubit devices and measurement tools that have the potential to revolutionize next-generation quantum computing. The standout advancement is the creation of qubits made from new materials that offer significant advantages over the materials used in the past two decades. Specifically, these qubits are constructed from tantalum, which forms a higher quality oxide layer than niobium, the material predominantly used by qubit manufacturers. Furthermore, tantalum is resilient to chemical cleaning, allowing for the fabrication of pristine surfaces and devices.

One of the key performance indicators for qubits is coherence time—how long a qubit can maintain a specific state. The tantalum qubits developed through this project consistently demonstrated coherence times three times longer than the current state-of-the-art, with lifetimes up to 0.5 ms. Multiple fabrication techniques were explored to identify the best methods, and insights were gained into the primary causes of decoherence, offering valuable guidance for future improvements.

In tandem with the development of qubits, the project also led to the creation of new precision measurement tools for quantum devices. Among these tools are advanced microscopy techniques capable of analyzing materials at the atomic scale. These methods allowed for the imaging and quantification of electrostatic disorder on material surfaces, as well as the detection and chemical identification of individual defects. Additionally, researchers observed how this disorder interacts with nearby electrons and how it can change dynamically when influenced by nearby electrodes.

Beyond the technical breakthroughs, this grant has helped establish a joint internship program with Princeton and IBM focused on quantum science called the Quantum Undergraduate Research at IBM and Princeton (QURIP) program, providing valuable industry experience to students. The program ran for 4 years, providing internships to 40 students, including 14 women and 7 underrepresented minority students. The majority of students that participated in QURIP went on to PhD programs after graduation, many in quantum science.

The grant also funded the development of a new control system for a scanning tunneling microscope, incorporating a haptic controller. This innovative system enables operators to "feel" surface structures and manipulate individual atoms through touch-based feedback. This control system is now used in routine operations and has been featured in outreach events where K-12 students have the unique opportunity to "touch" individual atoms.

In summary, this grant has advanced quantum computing technology, enhanced educational opportunities, and created novel tools that push the boundaries of both research and outreach.

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2024
Modified by: Victor W Brar
